title: Hollie Doyle interview: 'When I rode my first pony race I knew I was in training to be a jockey'
text:
Hollie Doyle is just seven winners short of becoming the third female Flat jockey to ride 100 winners in a calendar year but on Saturday she also has the chance of becoming the first to ride a winner on Qipco British Champions Day when she partners the mud-loving Glen Shiel in the £250,000 Balmoral Handicap.

Given that she rides for the prolific Archie Watson she should not only join Hayley Turner and Josephine Gordon in the girls’ 100 club but, with two months left, Gordon’s record of 106 winners in her sights.

If Cieren Fallon, the champion apprentice, has astounded people having only sat on a horse for the first time two years ago, Doyle’s upbringing was more traditional; virtually born in the saddle to parents – her father Mark rode for John Edwards - who both rode races and the same Pony Club in Herefordshire, albeit not at the same time as four time jump champion Richard Johnson.

“I didn’t have spectacular ponies, I had naughty, moderate ones but they taught me to ride,” she recalled. “I did everything but from the age of nine when I rode my first pony race I knew in my own mind that I was in training to be a jockey.

“I only rode four or five winners because the pony wasn’t good enough but it made me ultra-competitive from an early age and I was always in a hurry, expecting too much, when actually things just don’t happen that quickly.
